awd_titl_txt: EAGER: STEM Illinois: The Land-Grant Model of Outreach and Education to Nurture Future Underrepresented Computer Scientists
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite decades of computer science pipeline programming, participation of students of color in computer science and information technology disciplines remains alarmingly low. STEM Illinois is a project deeply rooted in the historic mission of land-grant institutions, which is to democratize higher education and to address the world?s most pressing societal challenges. This project will specifically work with 50 to 100 students whose parents do not have a college degree and who are at risk for dropping out of school. Computer scientists from these backgrounds represent a small number of faculty and industry professionals. The STEM Illinois project seeks to evaluate and analyze the impact of COVID-19 on their educational outcomes and pursuits by using a radical model of intergenerational outreach and education. This model seeks to create a culture of innovation where all members of the community see, understand, and feel that they can support their youth in computer science innovation. It is importance to understand which aspects of the culturally engaging project foster a computer science identity and persistence among the youth.

The goal of the STEM Illinois project is to create a unique ecosystem that will nurture future computer scientists in industry and the academy. This project will provide underrepresented students with computer science activities that include using spatial analysis to map communities vulnerable to COVID-19, coding, big data analysis, artificial intelligence, data visualization, math, algorithms, and access to a recording studio to represent computer science concepts using art and music. Students will receive unprecedented access to mentors and professional experiences that include interviewing industry/academic computing scientists for podcasts, giving TEDxYouth talks about their experiences with computer science, questions and answer sessions with Nobel Prize Winners, etc. This project will increase the number of marginalized students majoring in Computer Science and Information Technology at the University of Illinois and around the country. The goal is also to increase the number of students in computer science internships and jobs at large companies such as State Farm, American Association of Retired Persons (AARP) and Microsoft (workforce development). The project will be evaluated using pre- and post-tests surveys, interviews, and participant observation. The project will use the Computer Science Attitude and Identity Survey (or a similar instrument) that includes questions about how confident a person feels about their computer science skills and how much  interest  they have in computer science as a profession.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
STEM Illinois: The Land-Grant Model of Outreach and Education to Nurture Future Underrepresented Computer Scientists is deeply rooted in the land-grant mission and called the ?STEM Illinois Nobel Project.? Our students are referred to as Nobel scholars due to the belief that they will help to improve society like Nobel Laureates. We also have a DREAM incubator that layers computer science on top of what students love to do (e.g., creating video games and addressing health inequality).  Started during the COVID-19 pandemic in October 2020, the Nobel Project provided close to 150 mostly Black and Latinx middle and high school students unprecedented access to Computer Science (CS), CS-related careers, Community Health, Medicine and the arts (music production, AI art, etc.). Our Nobel Scholars live in urban (Chicago, IL), micro urban (Urbana-Champaign, IL) and mostly Black rural (Pembroke, IL) communities.

During 2020-2021, Nobel Scholars met weekly for two-hour Zoom sessions with Dr. Ruby Mendenhall, the Kathryn Lee Baynes Dallenbach LAS Professor in Sociology and African American Studies. Scholars also met with staff, students and guest speakers in Computer Science and related fields and who were mostly Black and Latinx. In year two (2021-2023), the training sessions decreased to two hours twice a month based on feedback that weekly was too intense. Our three goals include: (1) foster a computer science identity, (2) provide unprecedented access to CS and related fields, and (3) rally the entire community to support youths? pursuit of STEAM fields. 

Foster a Computer Science Identity. The Nobel Project provided around 66 sessions of CS and CS-related activities (e.g., coding; aerodynamics, Arduinos, farm robots, music production, oral histories) grounded in the Nobel Scholars? culture, lived experiences, passions and genius. For example, 7th grader Jaimya Freeman built a prototype of a Black girl robot named N1C?LE. N1C?LE has a black body and afro puffs and will help foster good mental health in children. Another Nobel Scholar, Adam DeLong, completed an oral history project where he combined his passions for computer science and music by composing music for the Project?s documentary using Bandlab app. Another scholar, Malik Muhammad, is a classically trained violinist. He plans to create a geometry music video using how he holds the violin bow to explain angles. Malik participated in the Carle Illinois College of Medicine?s Health Make-A-Thon. He and his father (Dr. Muhammad) won $10,000 worth of resources to play live classical music to foster calm and healing for family members of gunshot victims and COVID patients at hospitals, schools, and community centers. Malik created music for a documentary about mothers who lost adult children to gun violence, What?s Left Behind? He submitted his song?s idea to the Chicago Symphony Orchestra?s (CSO) Negaunee Music Institute: The Young Composers Initiative. He was selected and used the Flat app to compose his music. On April 24, 2022, an ensemble of the CSO played his song called ?Recoverless?: https://cso.org/experience/article/13664/five-young-composers-works-receive-premieres. Regarding being a Nobel Scholar,   Anllely Rivas states: ?I?m really proud of everything I?ve done. I feel like I?m a better person. I?m better at doing things and at school.?

Provide Unprecedented Access to CS.  We have crafted for Nobel Scholars a mostly Black and brown ecosystem of STEM faculty, staff, and graduate/undergraduate students; physicians; industry partners; and community programs/initiatives (who reflect the students) to give them real-world CS workforce experiences. Scholars gained expertise in carbon farming experiments; Java, Javascript, C+ and python coding; aerodynamics; Arduinos; farm robots; SpaceX carbon farming, etc. The Scholars have unprecedented access to Nobel Laureate Richard Roberts (and the late Robert Grubbs before his passing in 2021). Nobel Scholars, Diana and Anllely Rivas presented their projects at Dr. Martin Burke and Rachel Switzky?s NSF funded Molecule Maker Lab Institute planning workshop at the Beckman Institute.  

Rally the Entire Village for Support.  Nobel Project has a strong intergenerational emphasis and encourages caregivers, extended family member to participate by supporting their Scholars? involvement in activities and by participating in workshops and other events such as the Communiversity Think and Do Tank webcasts, family workshop nights on Thursdays, and talks by Nobel Laureates. At least two of the parents report using the Nobel Project activities to supplement their home-schooling curriculum. During the 2021 Illinois State Fair, the Project staff rallied the computer science experts to listen to and provide feedback to students after their presentations. Appreciation for this support and the Project was expressed by Nobel Scholar Briana White, ?I really enjoyed learning about aerodynamics?that was really an intriguing project...and it was really nice showing people [projects at the State Fair] because they seemed really interested in what we were doing.? Briana, also has a passion for wellness and was trained to be a Community Health Workers (and Citizen/Community Scientist) using Morehouse School of Medicine?s curriculum.   

 


Last Modified: 06/23/2023
Modified by: Ruby Mendenhall
